title: Why Does My Computer Keep Disconnecting from Wi-Fi? 10+ Potential Issues Behind Wi-Fi Connection

steps.title: It might be as simple as something blocking your connection.
steps.content: It might be as simple as something blocking your connection. If your computer is far away from your router, physical objects might be disrupting the wireless connection. Try moving closer to your router or shifting large things out of the way to see if that fixes your WiFi troubles. [1] X Research source Baby monitors, walkie-talkies, and radios tend to disrupt wireless connections. Try moving objects like these to another room to see if it strengthens your WiFi. [2] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021.

steps.title: Double check that all the connecting cables are plugged in and working.
steps.content: Double check that all the connecting cables are plugged in and working. The Ethernet cable is the one that connects the modem and the router, so it could be causing your disconnection issues. Try carefully unplugging the Ethernet cable, then plugging it back in to see if that solves your problem. [3] X Research source If your Ethernet cable is damaged, that could also be the issue. Head to a tech supply store to buy a new cable and install it.

steps.title: Sometimes, a simple on and off will reestablish your WiFi connection.
steps.content: Sometimes, a simple on and off will reestablish your WiFi connection. [4] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021. If you can’t figure out what’s going on with your WiFi, try carefully unplugging both your modem and your router, then plug them back in. It might take up to 5 minutes for your devices to reestablish a connection, so just hold tight! [5] X Research source This is a good time to double check that your Ethernet cable is connected and secure.

steps.title: A pending software update could be disrupting your WiFi connection.
steps.content: A pending software update could be disrupting your WiFi connection. Head into your settings and type “software” into the search bar, then check to see if you have any updates available. [6] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021. If you do, try installing them and then restarting your computer. If that was the issue, your WiFi should stop randomly disconnecting once the updates are installed. [7] X Research source Almost any software update could be disrupting the WiFi connection on your computer, no matter what it is. [8] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021.

steps.title: Some antivirus software will make your WiFi disconnect randomly.
steps.content: Some antivirus software will make your WiFi disconnect randomly. If you have an antivirus installed on your computer, try uninstalling it briefly to see if that strengthens your connection. If that was the problem, you may need to try a different antivirus program. [9] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021. Make sure your antivirus program is up to date, too. Outdated software could be causing your WiFi to disconnect. [10] X Research source

steps.title: In Windows, this feature reduces power consumption during low battery.
steps.content: In Windows, this feature reduces power consumption during low battery. However, some power management tools will disable the wireless adapter and cause your computer to disconnect from the WiFi. To check, head to Start > Device Manager > Network Adapters. Double click your WiFi’s name, then select the Power Management tab and uncheck the box that says “Allow the computer to turn off this device to save power.” [11] X Research source If this box was already unchecked, it means that the power management settings weren’t the problem.

steps.title: In Windows 10, this feature can cause some issues.
steps.content: In Windows 10, this feature can cause some issues. The WiFi-Sense tool constantly scans for new WiFi networks, which can cause your computer to randomly drop the one you’re already connected to. To turn this off, click Start, then head to your Settings. Select Network and Internet, then click Wi-Fi on the left. Click on Manage Wi-Fi Settings, then disable both “Connect to suggested open hotspots” and “Connect to networks shared by my friends.” [12] X Research source

steps.title: Drivers tell the computer how to interact with the software.
steps.content: Drivers tell the computer how to interact with the software. If the WiFi driver isn’t up to date, your computer won’t know how to interact with the wireless connection. To update your driver, head to Device Manager and then open up the Network Adapter section. Right click on the WiFi Adapter, then select “Update Driver Software.” [13] X Research source You may need to restart your computer after installing this update.

steps.title: Some computers don’t like interacting with multiple IP addresses.
steps.content: Some computers don’t like interacting with multiple IP addresses. [14] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021. By default, your router will assign your device a new IP address every time it interacts with it. To create a static one, log into your router on your computer and tell it to give you the same IP address every time. Every router is different, so you need to consult your user manual to find out how to access your specific device. [15] X Research source You can assign an IP address to your device for your router to use. Most routers will give you the first 3 digits, but the rest are up to you.

steps.title: Check out your router to see if any lights are not green.
steps.content: Check out your router to see if any lights are not green. If there is a red or a flashing light, it could mean that your router is having issues. [16] X Expert Source Luigi Oppido Computer & Tech Specialist Expert Interview. 30 September 2021. Check your user manual to see what each specific light means, and call your service provider to come and take a look at it if you need to. [17] X Research source If your router is the issue, the WiFi will probably randomly disconnect from all your devices, not just your computer.

steps.title: If nothing else works, it could be a problem with your provider.
steps.content: If nothing else works, it could be a problem with your provider. Check which internet provider you have, then give them a call and ask if there’s an outage in your area. If there is, you may just have to wait until they fix the outage before your connection is strong again. [18] X Research source Network service changes can also be a problem. You can ask your provider if they’ve made any changes recently and how that might have affected your WiFi.
